questions.question: A square is inscribed in an isosceles right triangle so that the square and the triangle have one angle common. Show that the vertex of the square opposite the vertex of the common angle bisects the hypotenuse.
questions.solution:
Let $\Delta ABC$ be an isosceles right triangle with $\angle A = 90^\circ$ and $AB = AC$.
Let ADEF be the square inscribed in it such that A is the common angle.
D lies on AB, F lies on AC, and E lies on BC.
Since ADEF is a square, $AD = AF$ and $DE = EF$.
Also, $DE \parallel AC$ and $EF \parallel AB$.
In $\Delta BDE$, $\angle BDE = 90^\circ$. Since $DE \parallel AC$, $\angle BED = \angle C = 45^\circ$ (Corresponding angles).
Thus, $\angle DBE = 45^\circ$, implying $BD = DE$.
Similarly, in $\Delta EFC$, $EF = FC$.
Since $AD = AF$ and $BD = FC$ (as $DE=EF$), we have $AB = AD + DB$ and $AC = AF + FC$.
Since $AB = AC$, this is consistent.
Now, in $\Delta BDE$ and $\Delta EFC$:
$BD = EF$ (since $BD=DE=EF$)
$\angle BDE = \angle EFC = 90^\circ$
$DE = FC$ (since $DE=EF=FC$)
By SAS congruence, $\Delta BDE \cong \Delta EFC$.
Therefore, $BE = EC$ (CPCT).
Hence, the vertex E bisects the hypotenuse BC.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="150" viewBox="0 0 200 150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="20,130 140,130 20,10" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><rect x="20" y="70" width="60" height="60" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: rgba(0,0,0,0.05);" /><text x="10" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="145" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="10" y="10" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="5" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="85" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">F</text><text x="85" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">E</text></g></svg>

questions.question: In a parallelogram ABCD, AB = 10 cm and AD = 6 cm. The bisector of $\angle A$ meets DC in E. AE and BC produced meet at F. Find the length of CF.
questions.solution:
Given ABCD is a parallelogram, so $AD \parallel BC$.
Transversal AF intersects parallel lines AD and BF.
$\angle DAE = \angle F$ (Alternate interior angles).
Since AE is the bisector of $\angle A$, $\angle DAE = \angle BAE$.
Therefore, $\angle BAE = \angle F$.
In $\Delta ABF$, since base angles are equal, sides opposite to them are equal.
$\Rightarrow AB = BF$.
Given $AB = 10$ cm, so $BF = 10$ cm.
From the figure, $BF = BC + CF$.
Since opposite sides of a parallelogram are equal, $BC = AD = 6$ cm.
$10 = 6 + CF$
$CF = 4$ cm.

questions.question: P, Q, R and S are respectively the mid-points of the sides AB, BC, CD and DA of a quadrilateral ABCD in which AC = BD and $AC \perp BD$. Prove that PQRS is a square.
questions.solution:
1. **Parallelogram**: In $\Delta ABC$, P and Q are mid-points, so $PQ \parallel AC$ and $PQ = \frac{1}{2}AC$. Similarly $SR \parallel AC$ and $SR = \frac{1}{2}AC$. Thus $PQ \parallel SR$ and $PQ = SR$, so PQRS is a parallelogram.
2. **Rhombus**: Similarly, $PS \parallel BD$ and $PS = \frac{1}{2}BD$. Since $AC = BD$, we have $PQ = PS$. A parallelogram with adjacent sides equal is a rhombus.
3. **Square**: Since $PQ \parallel AC$ and $PS \parallel BD$, and given $AC \perp BD$, it follows that $PQ \perp PS$. Thus $\angle P = 90^\circ$. A rhombus with a right angle is a square.

questions.question: A diagonal of a parallelogram bisects one of its angles. Show that it is a rhombus.
questions.solution:
Let ABCD be a parallelogram and diagonal AC bisect $\angle A$.
$\Rightarrow \angle DAC = \angle BAC$.
Since $AB \parallel DC$, alternate angles are equal: $\angle BAC = \angle DCA$.
From these two, $\angle DAC = \angle DCA$.
In $\Delta ADC$, sides opposite to equal angles are equal, so $AD = CD$.
Since adjacent sides of the parallelogram are equal, ABCD is a rhombus.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="120" viewBox="0 0 200 120" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="50,90 150,90 180,30 80,30" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="50" y1="90" x2="180" y2="30" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><text x="40" y="105" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="155" y="105" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="185" y="30" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="70" y="25" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text></g></svg>

questions.question: P and Q are the mid-points of the opposite sides AB and CD of a parallelogram ABCD. AQ intersects DP at S and BQ intersects CP at R. Show that PRQS is a parallelogram.
questions.solution:
Since ABCD is a parallelogram, $AB \parallel CD$ and $AB = CD$.
Since P and Q are mid-points, $AP = \frac{1}{2}AB$ and $CQ = \frac{1}{2}CD$.
Thus $AP = CQ$ and $AP \parallel CQ$.
Therefore, APCQ is a parallelogram.
$\Rightarrow AQ \parallel PC$ or $SQ \parallel PR$.
Similarly, $PB = DQ$ and $PB \parallel DQ$, so DPBQ is a parallelogram.
$\Rightarrow DP \parallel QB$ or $SP \parallel RQ$.
In quadrilateral PRQS, both pairs of opposite sides are parallel ($SQ \parallel PR$ and $SP \parallel RQ$).
Hence, PRQS is a parallelogram.
questions.diagram: <svg width="220" height="140" viewBox="0 0 220 140" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="40,110 180,110 210,40 70,40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="40" y1="110" x2="175" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="110" y1="110" x2="70" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="180" y1="110" x2="140" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="210" y1="40" x2="75" y2="110" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><text x="30" y="120" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="180" y="120" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="215" y="40" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="60" y="40" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="105" y="120" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">P</text><text x="140" y="35" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">Q</text><text x="90" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">S</text><text x="160" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">R</text></g></svg>

questions.question: ABCD is a quadrilateral in which $AB \parallel DC$ and $AD = BC$. Prove that $\angle A = \angle B$ and $\angle C = \angle D$.
questions.solution:
Extend AB and draw a line through C parallel to DA intersecting AB produced at E.
Since $AD \parallel CE$ and $AE \parallel DC$, ADCE is a parallelogram.
$\Rightarrow AD = CE$.
Given $AD = BC$, so $BC = CE$.
In $\Delta BCE$, $\angle CBE = \angle CEB$ (Angles opposite equal sides).
Now, $\angle A + \angle CEB = 180^\circ$ (Consecutive interior angles, $AD \parallel CE$).
And $\angle B + \angle CBE = 180^\circ$ (Linear pair).
Since $\angle CBE = \angle CEB$, we have $\angle A = \angle B$.
Also, in quadrilateral ABCD, $\angle A + \angle D = 180^\circ$ and $\angle B + \angle C = 180^\circ$.
Since $\angle A = \angle B$, it follows that $\angle C = \angle D$.
questions.diagram: <svg width="250" height="120" viewBox="0 0 250 120" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="40,100 140,100 120,40 60,40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="140" y1="100" x2="180" y2="100" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 4 2;" /><line x1="120" y1="40" x2="180" y2="100" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 4 2;" /><text x="30" y="110" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="135" y="110" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="120" y="35" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="55" y="35" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="185" y="110" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">E</text></g></svg>

questions.question: ABC is a triangle right angled at C. A line through the mid-point M of hypotenuse AB and parallel to BC intersects AC at D. Show that (i) D is the mid-point of AC (ii) $MD \perp AC$ (iii) $CM = MA = \frac{1}{2} AB$.
questions.solution:
(i) In $\Delta ABC$, M is the mid-point of AB and $MD \parallel BC$. By the converse of Mid-point Theorem, D is the mid-point of AC.
(ii) Since $MD \parallel BC$ and AC is transversal, $\angle ADM = \angle ACB$ (Corresponding angles).
Since $\angle ACB = 90^\circ$, $\angle ADM = 90^\circ$. Thus $MD \perp AC$.
(iii) In $\Delta AMD$ and $\Delta CMD$:
$AD = CD$ (D is mid-point)
$\angle ADM = \angle CDM = 90^\circ$
$MD = MD$ (Common)
By SAS rule, $\Delta AMD \cong \Delta CMD$.
$\Rightarrow MA = MC$ (CPCT).
Since M is mid-point of AB, $MA = \frac{1}{2}AB$.
Thus, $CM = MA = \frac{1}{2}AB$.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="150" viewBox="0 0 200 150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="20,130 180,130 180,20" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="100" y1="75" x2="180" y2="75" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="180" y1="130" x2="100" y2="75" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 4 2;" /><text x="10" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="185" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="185" y="15" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="90" y="70" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">M</text><text x="190" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text></g></svg>

questions.question: ABCD is a trapezium in which AB || DC and P and Q are points on AD and BC, respectively such that PQ || DC. If PD = 18 cm, BQ = 35 cm and QC = 15 cm, find AD.
questions.solution:
In trapezium ABCD, $AB \parallel DC$ and $PQ \parallel DC$. Thus, $AB \parallel PQ \parallel DC$.
By the Intercept Theorem (or Basic Proportionality Theorem applied by constructing a line parallel to AD through B), the intercepts made by parallel lines on transversals are proportional.
Therefore, $\frac{AP}{PD} = \frac{BQ}{QC}$.
Let $AP = x$.
$\frac{x}{18} = \frac{35}{15}$
$\frac{x}{18} = \frac{7}{3}$
$x = \frac{7 \times 18}{3} = 42$ cm.
Now, $AD = AP + PD = 42 + 18 = 60$ cm.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="140" viewBox="0 0 200 140" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="50,120 150,120 180,20 20,20" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="35" y1="70" x2="165" y2="70" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><text x="10" y="20" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="190" y="20" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="155" y="130" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="45" y="130" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="20" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">P</text><text x="170" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">Q</text></g></svg>

questions.question: Three parallel lines l, m and n are intersected by a transversal p at points A, B and C respectively and by transversal q at D, E and F respectively. If AB = BC, prove that DE = EF.
questions.solution:
Given $l \parallel m \parallel n$. Transversal p intersects them at A, B, C such that $AB = BC$.
We need to prove $DE = EF$.
Join A to F, intersecting line m at G.
In $\Delta ACF$, B is the mid-point of AC (since $AB=BC$) and $BG \parallel CF$ (since $m \parallel n$).
By the Mid-point Theorem (converse), G is the mid-point of AF.
Now in $\Delta AFD$, G is the mid-point of AF and $GE \parallel AD$ (since $m \parallel l$).
By the Mid-point Theorem (converse), E is the mid-point of DF.
Therefore, $DE = EF$.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="150" viewBox="0 0 200 150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><line x1="10" y1="20" x2="190" y2="20" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="10" y1="75" x2="190" y2="75" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="10" y1="130" x2="190" y2="130" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="40" y1="10" x2="80" y2="140" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="120" y1="10" x2="160" y2="140" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><text x="195" y="25" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">l</text><text x="195" y="80" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">m</text><text x="195" y="135" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">n</text><text x="30" y="20" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="50" y="70" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="70" y="130" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="110" y="20" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="130" y="70" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">E</text><text x="150" y="130" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">F</text></g></svg>

questions.question: In a parallelogram ABCD, E and F are the mid-points of sides AB and CD respectively. Show that the line segments AF and EC trisect the diagonal BD.
questions.solution:
Since ABCD is a parallelogram, $AB \parallel CD$ and $AB = CD$.
Since E and F are mid-points, $AE = \frac{1}{2}AB$ and $CF = \frac{1}{2}CD$.
Thus $AE = CF$ and $AE \parallel CF$.
Therefore, AECF is a parallelogram, so $AF \parallel EC$.
Let AF intersect BD at P and EC intersect BD at Q.
In $\Delta DQC$, F is mid-point of DC and $FP \parallel CQ$. By converse of Mid-point Theorem, P is mid-point of DQ $\Rightarrow DP = PQ$.
In $\Delta ABP$, E is mid-point of AB and $EQ \parallel AP$. By converse of Mid-point Theorem, Q is mid-point of BP $\Rightarrow PQ = QB$.
Thus, $DP = PQ = QB$. Hence, AF and EC trisect BD.
questions.diagram: <svg width="220" height="140" viewBox="0 0 220 140" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="40,110 180,110 210,40 70,40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="180" y1="110" x2="70" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="40" y1="110" x2="140" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="110" y1="110" x2="210" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><text x="30" y="120" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="180" y="120" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="215" y="40" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="60" y="40" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="105" y="125" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">E</text><text x="135" y="35" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">F</text><text x="100" y="70" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">P</text><text x="145" y="80" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">Q</text></g></svg>

questions.question: Show that the line segments joining the mid-points of the opposite sides of a quadrilateral bisect each other.
questions.solution:
Let ABCD be a quadrilateral. Let P, Q, R, S be the mid-points of sides AB, BC, CD, DA respectively.
Join PQ, QR, RS, SP and diagonal AC.
In $\Delta ABC$, P and Q are mid-points, so $PQ \parallel AC$ and $PQ = \frac{1}{2}AC$.
In $\Delta ADC$, S and R are mid-points, so $SR \parallel AC$ and $SR = \frac{1}{2}AC$.
Thus, $PQ \parallel SR$ and $PQ = SR$.
Therefore, PQRS is a parallelogram.
The diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other.
The diagonals of PQRS are PR and SQ, which are the line segments joining the mid-points of opposite sides of ABCD.
Hence, they bisect each other.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="140" viewBox="0 0 200 140" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="20,80 100,120 180,60 80,20" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><polygon points="60,100 140,90 130,40 50,50" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 4 2; fill: none;" /><line x1="60" y1="100" x2="130" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="140" y1="90" x2="50" y2="50" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><text x="10" y="80" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="100" y="135" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="190" y="60" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="75" y="15" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="50" y="115" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">P</text><text x="150" y="100" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">Q</text><text x="135" y="35" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">R</text><text x="40" y="45" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">S</text></g></svg>

questions.question: E and F are respectively the mid-points of the non-parallel sides AD and BC of a trapezium ABCD. Prove that EF || AB and EF = 1/2 (AB + CD).
questions.solution:
Join AC and let it intersect EF at O.
In $\Delta ADC$, E is the mid-point of AD. Since EF is the line segment joining mid-points of non-parallel sides, we can prove $EF \parallel AB \parallel DC$.
Since $EO \parallel DC$ and E is mid-point of AD, O is mid-point of AC and $EO = \frac{1}{2}DC$.
In $\Delta ABC$, O is mid-point of AC and $OF \parallel AB$. Thus F is mid-point of BC (given) and $OF = \frac{1}{2}AB$.
Therefore, $EF = EO + OF = \frac{1}{2}DC + \frac{1}{2}AB = \frac{1}{2}(AB + CD)$.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="120" viewBox="0 0 200 120" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="40,100 160,100 140,40 60,40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="50" y1="70" x2="150" y2="70" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><line x1="40" y1="100" x2="140" y2="40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 4 2;" /><text x="30" y="110" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="170" y="110" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="145" y="35" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="55" y="35" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="35" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">E</text><text x="160" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">F</text><text x="95" y="65" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">O</text></g></svg>

questions.question: Prove that the quadrilateral formed by the bisectors of the angles of a parallelogram is a rectangle.
questions.solution:
Let ABCD be a parallelogram. Let bisectors of $\angle A$ and $\angle B$ meet at P, $\angle B$ and $\angle C$ at Q, $\angle C$ and $\angle D$ at R, and $\angle D$ and $\angle A$ at S.
We know $\angle A + \angle B = 180^\circ$ (Adjacent angles).
$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}\angle A + \frac{1}{2}\angle B = 90^\circ$.
In $\Delta APB$, $\angle APB = 180^\circ - (\frac{1}{2}\angle A + \frac{1}{2}\angle B) = 180^\circ - 90^\circ = 90^\circ$.
Thus $\angle SPQ = 90^\circ$ (Vertically opposite to $\angle APB$ if formed internally, or directly if P is the vertex).
Similarly, we can prove $\angle PQR = 90^\circ$, $\angle QRS = 90^\circ$, and $\angle RSP = 90^\circ$.
A quadrilateral with all angles $90^\circ$ is a rectangle.
questions.diagram: <svg width="220" height="140" viewBox="0 0 220 140" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="40,110 180,110 210,40 70,40" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><polygon points="110,95 160,75 140,55 90,75" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: rgba(0,0,0,0.05);" /><line x1="40" y1="110" x2="140" y2="55" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 2 2;" /><line x1="180" y1="110" x2="90" y2="75" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 2 2;" /><line x1="210" y1="40" x2="110" y2="95" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 2 2;" /><line x1="70" y1="40" x2="160" y2="75" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; stroke-dasharray: 2 2;" /><text x="30" y="120" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="180" y="120" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="215" y="40" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="60" y="40" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text></g></svg>

questions.question: P and Q are points on opposite sides AD and BC of a parallelogram ABCD such that PQ passes through the point of intersection O of its diagonals AC and BD. Show that PQ is bisected at O.
questions.solution:
In $\Delta POD$ and $\Delta QOB$:
$\angle PDO = \angle QBO$ (Alternate interior angles, $AD \parallel BC$)
$OD = OB$ (Diagonals of parallelogram bisect each other)
$\angle POD = \angle QOB$ (Vertically opposite angles)
By ASA congruence rule, $\Delta POD \cong \Delta QOB$.
Therefore, $PO = OQ$ (CPCT).
Hence, PQ is bisected at O.

questions.question: ABCD is a rectangle in which diagonal BD bisects $\angle B$. Show that ABCD is a square.
questions.solution:
Given ABCD is a rectangle, so $\angle B = 90^\circ$.
Since BD bisects $\angle B$, $\angle ABD = \angle CBD = 45^\circ$.
In $\Delta ABD$, $\angle A = 90^\circ$ and $\angle ABD = 45^\circ$.
Therefore, $\angle ADB = 180^\circ - (90^\circ + 45^\circ) = 45^\circ$.
Since $\angle ABD = \angle ADB$, the sides opposite to them are equal: $AD = AB$.
A rectangle with adjacent sides equal is a square.
questions.diagram: <svg width="150" height="150" viewBox="0 0 150 150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><rect x="25" y="25" width="100" height="100" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><line x1="125" y1="125" x2="25" y2="25" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1;" /><text x="15" y="20" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="135" y="20" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="135" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="15" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text></g></svg>

questions.question: D, E and F are respectively the mid-points of the sides AB, BC and CA of a triangle ABC. Prove that by joining these mid-points D, E and F, the triangle ABC is divided into four congruent triangles.
questions.solution:
Since D and F are mid-points of AB and AC, $DF \parallel BC$ and $DF = \frac{1}{2}BC = BE$.
Thus, DBEF is a parallelogram. Diagonal DE divides it into two congruent triangles: $\Delta DBE \cong \Delta FED$.
Similarly, DECF is a parallelogram and $\Delta EFC \cong \Delta FED$.
And ADEF is a parallelogram and $\Delta ADF \cong \Delta FED$.
Therefore, all four triangles ($\Delta ADF, \Delta DBE, \Delta EFC, \Delta FED$) are congruent.
questions.diagram: <svg width="200" height="150" viewBox="0 0 200 150" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g><polygon points="20,130 180,130 100,20" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: none;" /><polygon points="60,75 140,75 100,130" style="stroke: black; stroke-width: 1; fill: rgba(0,0,0,0.05);" /><text x="10" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">B</text><text x="185" y="140" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">C</text><text x="95" y="15" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">A</text><text x="45" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">D</text><text x="145" y="75" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">F</text><text x="100" y="145" style="font: 14px serif; fill: black;">E</text></g></svg>

questions.question: Prove that the line joining the mid-points of the diagonals of a trapezium is parallel to the parallel sides and is equal to half of their difference.
questions.solution:
Let ABCD be a trapezium with $AB \parallel DC$. Let M and N be mid-points of diagonals AC and BD.
Join CN and produce it to meet AB at P.
In $\Delta CDN$ and $\Delta PBN$:
$\angle DNC = \angle BNP$ (Vertically opposite)
$DN = BN$ (N is mid-point)
$\angle CDN = \angle PBN$ (Alternate interior angles)
$\Delta CDN \cong \Delta PBN$ (ASA).
$\Rightarrow CN = PN$ and $CD = PB$.
In $\Delta CAP$, M is mid-point of AC and N is mid-point of CP.
By Mid-point Theorem, $MN \parallel AP$ (so $MN \parallel AB$) and $MN = \frac{1}{2}AP$.
$AP = AB - PB = AB - CD$.
Therefore, $MN = \frac{1}{2}(AB - CD)$.

questions.question: Parallelogram ABCD, E and F are points on side AB and CD respectively such that AE = CF. Show that BFDE is a parallelogram.
questions.solution:
Since ABCD is a parallelogram, $AB \parallel CD$ and $AB = CD$.
Given $AE = CF$.
Since $AB = CD$, we have $AB - AE = CD - CF$, which implies $EB = DF$.
Also, since $AB \parallel CD$, parts of parallel lines are parallel, so $EB \parallel DF$.
In quadrilateral BFDE, one pair of opposite sides (EB and DF) is equal and parallel.
Therefore, BFDE is a parallelogram.
